short-title.#text:
Justice and Mental Health
			 Collaboration Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/s:2991/ss:i
Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/s:2991/ss:l

			 2991 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 2991 of the
			 Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/s:2991

text.#text:
In
				this subsection:

term.#tail:
means services or programs that connect qualified veterans with
				other veterans for the purpose of providing support and mentorship to assist
				qualified veterans in obtaining treatment, recovery, stabilization, or
				rehabilitation.
term.#text:
peer to peer services or
				programs

text.#text: The term

header.#text:
Peer to peer
				services or programs

text.#text:
has served on
				active duty in any branch of the Armed Forces, including the National Guard and
				reserve components; and

was discharged
				or released from such service under conditions other than dishonorable.

term.#tail:
means a
				preliminarily qualified offender who—

text.#text: The term

alternatives to
				incarceration; and

other
				appropriate services, including housing, transportation, mentoring, employment,
				job training, education, and assistance in applying for and obtaining available
				benefits.

term.#tail:
means a court program involving collaboration among criminal
				justice, veterans, and mental health and substance abuse agencies that provides
				qualified veterans with—

text.#text: The term

veterans
				treatment court programs;

peer to peer
				services or programs for qualified veterans;

practices that
				identify and provide treatment, rehabilitation, legal, transitional, and other
				appropriate services to qualified veterans who have been incarcerated;
				and

training
				programs to teach criminal justice, law enforcement, corrections, mental
				health, and substance abuse personnel how to identify and appropriately respond
				to incidents involving qualified veterans.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, may award grants under this subsection to applicants to
				establish or expand—

text.#text: The

promote
				effective strategies to identify and reduce the risk of harm to qualified
				veterans and public safety; and

propose
				interventions with empirical support to improve outcomes for qualified
				veterans.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall give priority
				to applications that—

text.#text:
In
				awarding grants under this subsection, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/s:2991/ss:i
Justice and Mental Health Collaboration Act of 2013/s:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 2991 of the
			 Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/s:2991

term.#tail:
means a
				jail, prison, or other detention facility used to house people who have been
				arrested, detained, held, or convicted by a criminal justice agency or a
				court.

text.#text: The term

is being held,
				detained, or incarcerated in a correctional facility; and

manifests
				obvious signs of a mental illness or has been diagnosed by a qualified mental
				health professional as having a mental illness.
The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may award grants to
				applicants to enhance the capabilities of a correctional facility—

text.#text: The

to identify and
				screen for eligible inmates;

to plan and
				provide—

to develop,
				implement, and enhance—

post-release
				transition plans for eligible inmates that, in a comprehensive manner,
				coordinate health, housing, medical, employment, and other appropriate services
				and public benefits;

alternatives to
				solitary confinement and segregated housing and mental health screening and
				treatment for inmates placed in solitary confinement or segregated housing;
				and

to train each
				employee of the correctional facility to identify and appropriately respond to
				incidents involving inmates with mental health or co-occuring mental health and
				substance abuse
				disorders.

Justice and Mental Health Collaboration Act of 2013/s:3

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 2991 of the
			 Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/s:2991

header.#text:
Demonstration
				grants responding to high utilizers

text.#text:
In
				this subsection, the term

manifests obvious
				signs of mental illness or has been diagnosed by a qualified mental health
				professional as having a mental illness; and

consumes a
				significantly disproportionate quantity of public resources, such as emergency,
				housing, judicial, corrections, and law enforcement services.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may award not more than 6 grants per
				year under this subsection to applicants for the purpose of reducing the use of
				public services by high utilizers.

text.#text: The

to provide
				training on how to respond appropriately to the unique issues involving high
				utilizers for public service personnel, including criminal justice, mental
				health, substance abuse, emergency room, healthcare, law enforcement,
				corrections, and housing personnel;

to develop or
				support alternatives to hospital and jail admissions for high utilizers that
				provide treatment, stabilization, and other appropriate supports in the least
				restrictive, yet appropriate, environment; or

to develop
				protocols and systems among law enforcement, mental health, substance abuse,
				housing, corrections, and emergency medical service operations to provide
				coordinated assistance to high utilizers.

A recipient of a grant awarded under this subsection may
				use the grant—

measures the
				performance of the grant recipient in reducing the use of public services by
				high utilizers; and

provides a model
				set of practices, systems, or procedures that other jurisdictions can adopt to
				reduce the use of public services by high
				utilizers.

Not
				later than the last day of the first year following the fiscal year in which a
				grant is awarded under this subsection, the recipient of the grant shall submit
				to the

header.#text:
Demonstration
				grants responding to high utilizers

,

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/s:2991/ss:h/p:1

text.#text: in

To provide support for academy curricula, law
				enforcement officer orientation programs, continuing education training, and
				other programs that teach law enforcement personnel how to identify and respond
				to incidents involving persons with mental health disorders or co-occuring
				mental health and substance abuse
				disorders.

by adding at the
			 end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, in awarding grants under this
				subsection, shall give priority to programs that law enforcement personnel and
				members of the mental health and substance abuse professions develop and
				administer
				cooperatively.

term.#tail:
means an adult or juvenile
				accused of an offense who—

text.#text: The term

manifests obvious signs of mental
				illness or co-occurring mental illness and substance abuse disorders during
				arrest or confinement or before any court; or

in the case of a veterans treatment
				court provided under subsection (i), has been diagnosed with, or manifests
				obvious signs of, mental illness or a substance abuse disorder or co-occuring
				mental illness and substance abuse disorder; and

has been
				unanimously approved for participation in a program funded under this section
				by, when appropriate, the relevant—

prosecuting
				attorney;

defense
				attorney;

probation or
				corrections official;

judge;
				and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/s:2991/ss:b/p:5/sp:B/cl:i

text.#text:
a representative
				from the relevant mental health agency described in

the views of
				any relevant victims to the offense;

the extent to
				which the defendant would benefit from participation in the program;

the extent to
				which the community would realize cost savings because of the defendant's
				participation in the program; and

whether the
				defendant satisfies the eligibility criteria for program participation
				unanimously established by the relevant prosecuting attorney, defense attorney,
				probation or corrections official, judge and mental health or substance abuse
				agency
				representative.

In
				determining whether to designate a defendant as a preliminarily qualified
				offender, the relevant prosecuting attorney, defense attorney, probation or
				corrections official, judge, and mental health or substance abuse agency
				representative shall take into account—

text.#text:
does not have as
				an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against
				the person or property of another; or

is not a felony
				that by its nature involves a substantial risk that physical force against the
				person or property of another may be used in the course of committing the
				offense.
